item.title: The 'quite simple' way this group of Australians could save lives
item.description: Australians receiving treatment for "urgent" and "critical" diseases are having to wait for people overseas to make life-saving donations.

item.title: 'Not exactly glamorous': The 'disheartening' reality of dating in rural Australia
item.description: Rural Australians say dating in the country is a whole lot harder than in the city, with geographic isolation the least of their worries. Finding someone with the same values and lifestyle priorities is often the hardest challenge, which is why singles events in the sticks are having such a big impact.

item.title: The UN has reached a historic milestone. The world will be watching what it does next
item.description: This week's United Nations meeting will be a landmark occasion for multiple reasons.

item.title: Opinions divided on how to save our precious mountain ash forests
item.description: New research has found Australia's heat-stressed forests are rapidly thinning, and could even be producing carbon emissions. It comes as the government prepares to release its 2035 emissions targets and a climate risk report later this month. But local researchers, politicians and Traditional Owner land groups remain divided on how to protect the forest.

item.title: White House issues clarification after Trump hits H-1B visas with $150,000 fee
item.description: The announcement sparked concerns among employees across swaths of corporate America.

item.title: At least 60 Palestinians killed as Israel presses on with Gaza City assault
item.description: The Israeli military estimates it has demolished up to 20 Gaza City tower blocks over the past two weeks.

item.title: Republicans warn Australia of 'punitive measures' recognising Palestinian statehood
item.description: Anthony Albanese will recognise Palestinian statehood along with other world leaders at the UN General Assembly this week.

item.title: 'Remarkable': How Gaza protests unfolded in Australia and around the world
item.description: Australia is considered a "low protest country" but it has held some of the biggest pro-Palestinian protests in the world. Explore how Gaza protests have unfolded in our interactive map.

item.title: Some Australians are not confident about their retirement. Here's how much you need a year
item.description: Australians looking for work in their 40s and women, especially those divorced or single with children, are not feeling confident about retirement.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 22 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Prosecutors to consider charges as police end investigation into Kumanjayi White's death
item.description: A mandatory coronial investigation into the death in custody of Kumanjayi White remains ongoing.

item.title: Albanese in New York: Will the PM finally meet Trump — and what happens if he doesn't?
item.description: The prime minister has wasted no time since arriving in the Big Apple. What lies ahead?

item.title: Why Brooke chose Facebook over an IVF clinic to find a sperm donor
item.description: As demand for sperm donors increases, some are avoiding fertility clinics in favour of less formal networks. Meanwhile, for donors, there is a range of ethical considerations and potential unintended consequences to consider.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel show returning to air after suspension over Charlie Kirk comments
item.description: Disney said it had initially suspended Kimmel's show "to avoid further inflaming a tense situation at an emotional moment for our country."

item.title: Why many Australians don't feel financially confident & ASX rises as market waits for US inflation
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Luke McMillan from Ophir Asset Management about the day's sharemarket action while Stephanie Youssef looks through the latest AMP research with Ben Hillier which reveals half of Australians don't feel financially confident as they approach retirement.

item.title: 'A uniquely delicate crime': Dangers of stealthing poorly understood by Australians
item.description: Stealthing, the removal of a condom during sex without a partner's knowledge or consent, has in recent years become a criminal offence in almost all parts of Australia. But experts say there is still a lack of awareness about what stealthing is and the dangers it poses.

item.title: Qantas warns of flight disruptions as Typhoon Ragasa approaches Hong Kong
item.description: Thousands of people have been evacuated in the northern Philippines as one of the strongest typhoons this year threatens to cause flooding and landslides.

item.title: Albanese uses UN speech to call on Israel to 'accept responsibility' over Gaza 'catastrophe'
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has called for an Israeli-Palestinian two-state solution at a high-level address at the UN General Assembly.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 23 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: The states and territories where renters have it the best — and worst
item.description: Two years after a national pledge to deliver a 'Better Deal for Renters', a new report finds progress remains uneven — with rights still dictated by postcode.

item.title: Nvidia's huge OpenAI deal, and Myer's profit tumbles
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Michael McCarthy from MooMoo Australia about the day's market action including Myer's disappointing profit result, and Nvidia's huge OpenAI deal.

item.title: Are your blueberries safe? Why a pesticide scare has some concerned
item.description: Pesticide suspended after tests on store-bought berries found high levels of harmful chemicals.

item.title: Third time's a charm? Albanese and Trump meeting confirmed for next month
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has finally locked in a formal face-to-face meeting with Donald Trump, after a number of false starts.

item.title: Third time's a charm? Albanese and Trump meeting confirmed for next month
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has finally locked in a formal face-to-face meeting with Donald Trump, after a number of false starts.

item.title: Australian doctors describe 'slaughterhouse' in Gaza hospital as medicine runs out
item.description: Two Australian doctors volunteering in one of Gaza's last functioning hospitals say nothing prepared them for what they have witnessed in the past two weeks.

item.title: These girls are only able to study in secret. For many, their 'last hope' is being taken away
item.description: With a new internet ban in the north of Afghanistan in force, members of the diaspora in Australia worry their families will be even more isolated.

item.title: Countries 'going to hell' and other key takeaways from Donald Trump's UN speech
item.description: Trump warned that migration is sending Western nations "to hell" and dismissed climate change as a "con job".

item.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: Cyclone bears down on southern China after 17 killed in Taiwan
item.description: Millions of people in southern China are in Typhoon Ragasa's sights after the most powerful cyclone of 2025 battered Hong Kong and killed 17 people in Taiwan.

item.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: Cyclone bears down on southern China after 17 killed in Taiwan
item.description: Millions of people in southern China are in Typhoon Ragasa's sights after the most powerful cyclone of 2025 battered Hong Kong and killed 17 people in Taiwan.

item.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: Cyclone bears down on southern China after 17 killed in Taiwan
item.description: Millions of people in southern China are in Typhoon Ragasa's sights after the most powerful cyclone of 2025 battered Hong Kong and killed 17 people in Taiwan.

item.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: Cyclone bears down on southern China after 17 killed in Taiwan
item.description: Millions of people in southern China are in Typhoon Ragasa's sights after the most powerful cyclone of 2025 battered Hong Kong and killed 17 people in Taiwan.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 24 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: NT hit-and-run case spotlights deep disparities in criminal justice system, advocates say
item.description: The Northern Territory has been engulfed by significant backlash regarding the sentencing of a driver who fatally struck an Aboriginal man in a hit and run and his familial connection to the Territory's Attorney General. First Nations communities and legal experts argue the sentence given to Jake Danby, a 12-month community corrections order, is inconsistent with the 'tough on crime' approach of the Country Liberal Party government.

item.title: Aboriginal people report less respectful hospital care. Here's what can make a difference
item.description: More than a quarter of Aboriginal patients said there had been a time in the past year they needed to go to hospital but didn't, a report has found.

item.title: 'Should've done more': Commissioner's apology at Tian Jarrah Denniss inquest
item.description: The Corrective Services NSW commissioner has delivered an apology to the family of Indigenous man Tian Jarrah Denniss, who died in custody in 2023.

item.title: Three-year inflation high could mean 'wafer-thin' chance of interest rate cut pre November
item.description: Freshly released inflation data will prompt the Reserve Bank to keep the cash rate on hold in September, but a cut in November is still "very much on the cards", experts say.

item.title: President Trump's extraordinary address at the UN General Assembly
item.description: Donald Trump has stunned the United Nations, using his speech at the General Assembly to suggest other countries are “going to hell” because of migration and denying science by calling climate change a ‘con’. In an extraordinary address, he slammed the UN for not doing enough to end wars. The US President also said he’d support NATO countries shooting down a Russian aircraft that breaches their airspace, and declared Kyiv can win back ‘all of Ukraine’.

item.title: Higher inflation threatens rate cuts & is the US market overvalued?
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Paul Bloxham from HSBC about today's stronger than expected inflation figures and what it means for interest rates, plus the day on the sharemarket with Francesco De Stradis from Ord Minnett.

item.title: This Christian community embraces traditional living. But ex-members allege it has dark secrets
item.description: When Dateline journalist Rhiona-Jade Armont travelled to the US for a story about tradwives, she’d never heard of Homestead Heritage. She soon learned the Christian group had a dark history of abuse — and former members allege there’s more. But current members and leaders say it’s a sovereign sanctuary from the outside world.

item.title: Greta Thunberg calls alleged drone attacks on aid flotilla a 'scare tactic' as UN demands probe
item.description: The United Nations has called for an independent investigation into alleged drone attacks on the Global Sumud Flotilla, an international convoy carrying humanitarian aid to Gaza.

item.title: Greta Thunberg calls alleged drone attacks on aid flotilla a 'scare tactic' as UN demands probe
item.description: The United Nations has called for an independent investigation into alleged drone attacks on the Global Sumud Flotilla, an international convoy carrying humanitarian aid to Gaza.

item.title: 'Warm chat' and a selfie: Albanese finally comes face-to-face with Trump
item.description: Anthony Albanese has met Donald Trump at the president's welcome reception for world leaders in New York after the pair locked in a formal sit-down for October.

item.title: Albanese pushes for Security Council seat and calls out Iran in first major UN speech
item.description: The UN risks "being trusted with nothing" unless it works together to tackle climate change and end wars in Gaza and Ukraine, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has said during his first UN General Assembly address.

item.title: When will humans return to the moon? NASA's new mission is offering clues
item.description: The last time humans landed on the moon was in December 1972.

item.title: When will humans return to the moon? NASA's new mission is offering clues
item.description: The last time humans landed on the moon was in December 1972.

item.title: Anthony Albanese makes the case for Australia at the UN
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has delivered his first leader's speech to the United Nations General Assembly, promoting Australia as a significant middle power. He's used the speech to push for more global co-operation on tackling the climate crisis, and peacekeeping efforts. And he's also pushing for Australia to co-host the next COP climate summit in 2026, and hold a seat on the UN Security Council.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 25 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 'Thanks for waking me up': Untold story behind Cathy Freeman's Olympic glory
item.description: On the 25th anniversary of Cathy Freeman's 400m gold win at the Sydney Olympics, John-Paul Janke looks back at the time she stayed at his home in Canberra.

item.title: It's 'third time lucky' for an Alzheimer's drug. But many Australians like Peter will miss out
item.description: Australia's medicines watchdog has approved Alzheimer's drug lecanemab, which has been shown to "significantly" extend quality of life. But it comes at a great cost.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Penny Wong on the upcoming Albanese-Trump meeting and Australia's bid to host COP31
item.description: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the upcoming meeting between Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump will seek to advance areas of co-operation but also underline issues of sovereignty.

item.title: Special Episode: Palestine recognition, Trump unfiltered & paracetamol panic
item.description: Ten Western nations (including Australia, the UK, and France) formally recognise a Palestinian state at the UN General Assembly. Our correspondents bring you the latest from New York, as they break down the statehood debate, MAGA’s escalating war on the left, and Trump’s unsubstantiated claims linking paracetamol and autism.

item.title: New research shows more Australians being harmed by gambling
item.description: An increasing number of Australians are being harmed by gambling according to new research. The study highlights the link between problem gambling and domestic violence, suicide, and financial hardship, with more than 3-million Australians said to be impacted.

item.title: Industries at risk of technology and AI & big dividend day
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves delves into Barrenjoey's report on the industries most exposed to technological change and AI with Johnathan McMenamin; plus the day on the sharemarket with Mark Gardner from MPC Markets.

item.title: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy jailed for five years over Libyan criminal conspiracy case
item.description: Sarkozy, who has always denied the charges, was accused of making a deal with former Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi to obtain campaign financing.

item.title: Australia's battle to take out a rival bid and host its 'biggest diplomatic summit ever'
item.description: The summit would likely provide an economic boost for the hopeful host city, Adelaide, after a record 80,000 people attended last year's event in Dubai.

item.title: From Silicon Valley to Sydney: How Trump's H-1B visa move could make ripples in Australia
item.description: As Donald Trump's H-1B visa order seeks to restrict the United States' intake of skilled migrants, could it provide an opportunity for Australia?

item.title: 'Unauthorised' edit of Australian film Together removes same-sex couple for audiences in China
item.description: The film Together has reportedly been altered using artificial intelligence by a Chinese film distributor.

item.title: Donald Trump says any Israeli annexation of the West Bank is 'not going to happen'
item.description: The US president has rejected calls from some members of the Israeli prime minister's coalition for Israel to fully annex the West Bank.

item.title: 'Unusual': Passenger on board Qantas flight speaks after emergency landing
item.description: The plane landed safely at Auckland Airport after concerns of a fire in the cargo hold. The local ambulance service said no passengers on board required its assistance.

item.title: Trump overcomes 'resistance' from China to transfer TikTok to US investors
item.description: The US president said Rupert Murdoch, along with other "world-class investors", would be involved in the deal.

item.title: Donald Trump announces 100% tariffs on branded medicines from October
Who is James Comey, the Trump critic and ex-FBI director who has just been indicted?
item.description: James Comey, who was fired by Donald Trump during the US president's first term, has been charged with two criminal counts.

item.title: Gaza death toll exceeds 65,500 as Israeli military intensifies strikes on enclave
item.description: The war in Gaza has now claimed more than 65,500 lives, according to Palestinian health officials, as Israeli forces intensify their campaign both inside the Strip and beyond. While Israel expands air and ground operations deep into Yemen, Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas is calling for a post-Hamas future and an immediate ceasefire.

item.title: The rise and fall of France's Nicolas Sarkozy after conviction
item.description: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been sentenced to five years in prison after being found guilty of criminal conspiracy.

item.title: Butler criticises Trump's 'unfair' pharma tariffs that Ley says are 'shocking but unsurprising'
item.description: Medicines and pharmaceuticals are among Australia's top exports to the US, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 25 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: UN says millions of young people are being left behind
item.description: Youth advocates from around the world have gathered at the UN headquarters in New York to participate in the high-level plenary meeting of the General Assembly. Their meeting marked the thirtieth anniversary of the World Programme of Action for Youth.

item.title: 'Exclusion or punishment': Fears of a growing problem in Australian schools
item.description: There's an anti-Palestinian racism "crisis" in Australian schools, according to a new report by an advocacy group, with students and teachers being punished for showing support for the Palestinian cause.

item.title: What time does the 2025 AFL grand final start? All the key details to know
item.description: Around 100,000 people are anticipated to go to the Geelong v Brisbane match this weekend.

item.title: Pharma stocks tumble following US pharma import tariffs
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Shane Oliver from AMP and Marcus Bogdan from Blackmore Capital about the reaction to a US decision to apply 100% import tariffs to pharmaceutical products from Wednesday, plus all the latest from the sharemarket.

item.title: How a radical three-month experiment changed Australia's TV landscape forever
item.description: Celebrating five decades on air, a landmark SBS documentary shows how a radical idea evolved into a national platform for Indigenous and multicultural storytelling.

item.title: Court drops terror-related charge against member of Irish rap group Kneecap
item.description: The punk-rap group has issued a statement saying "they do not, and have never, supported Hamas or Hezbollah".

item.title: Anthony Albanese to meet King Charles, consult Middle East peace during UK visit
item.description: Anthony Albanese has swapped the US for the UK, landing in London for political talks and a conference of global leaders.

item.title: Dreaming of spreadsheets and battling stage fright: Behind the world Excel championships
item.description: From spreadsheets to showdowns, the Excel World Championship turns number-crunching into a high-stakes spectacle.

item.title: Australia has around 100,000 eggs in IVF storage. Some want to see unclaimed eggs donated
item.description: The demand for eggs far outpaces the number donated in Australia, leaving those wanting to start families with few options. Experts say something needs to change.

item.title: What's next for South Australia's algae bloom?
item.description: South Australia's algal bloom continues to spread, leading to significant environmental, ecological and mental health harm. Those impacts have been heard at a Senate inquiry examining support arrangements for those affected, but also long-term prevention strategies.

item.title: Dozens walk out on Netanyahu UN speech calling Palestinian recognition a 'mark of shame'
item.description: A procession of delegates exited the United Nations General Assembly hall ahead of Benjamin Netanyahu's speech denouncing Australia, France, Britain, Canada and other countries for recognising a Palestinian state.

item.title: New deep space antenna in Australia to aid exploration of universe while also creating local jobs
item.description: More than three years after it was first announced, a new deep space antenna is being brought online in Western Australia.

item.title: How to deep clean your fridge ahead of summer
item.description: Those neglected items at the back of your fridge can become a health hazard.

item.title: Six-pack diplomacy: Albanese joins Starmer and Carney for high-stakes talks
item.description: The Australian, British and Canadian leaders used a London summit to warn against the far-right and to discuss migration and renewed support for Palestinian statehood.

item.title: A mass delegate walk-out and what comes next: Benjamin Netanyahu's speech to the UN
item.description: Speaking at the United Nations, the Israeli leader pushed back in his harshest terms yet against a flurry of diplomatic moves that have deepened Israel's international isolation. But one thing was missing — any suggestion for what comes next, besides more war.

item.title: Trump isn't the first to push an unproven claim about autism. Why are they so pervasive?
item.description: One expert says an "information void" has allowed non-evidence-based claims and conspiracy theories around autism to flourish.

item.title: Afraid of AI replacing you? Here are jobs that may be future-proof
item.description: Jobs including tax preparation, legal advice and education may have the lowest risk of being replaced by technology.

item.title: 'Is this still happening?': Elon Musk named in new Epstein files
item.description: Prince Andrew and PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel are among the other names in the documents released by Democrat politicians.

item.title: New Zealand won't recognise a Palestinian state 'at this time'
item.description: The decision puts the country at odds with its Commonwealth allies Australia, Canada and the United Kingdom.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Could a new UN declaration protect aid workers amid the growing death toll?
item.description: More than 100 states have signed an Australian-led declaration to protect aid workers. Australian Red Cross CEO Andrew Colvin explains what the declaration is aiming to achieve.

item.title: 'Peeling back the water': How these women are mapping ancient whale migration paths
item.description: A trio of First Nations researchers is blending traditional knowledge and science to map whale migration and advocate for improved conservation.

item.title: 'Jekyll and Hyde': How to win over Australia's most polarising bird
item.description: Culturally revered in Dreamtime stories but feared by cyclists, the magpie has a "Jekyll and Hyde" presence in our suburbs. But one expert says there are ways to win them over — even if you're magpie enemy number one.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Footballer Fandi Ahmad is a Singaporean sporting legend: We find out why
item.description: Fandi Ahmad is more than just a footballer; has been described as a national legend in Singapore. He was the first Singaporean footballer to play in Europe, the first Singaporean millionaire sportsperson and the first Singaporean sportsperson to have a published biography. As a young child, his family lived in a two-room public housing flat, Fandi was obsessed with football and spent much of his time kicking a ball. He became arguably Asia's best known footballer. He's shared the pitch with Diego Maradona, and was picked to play for Dutch football giant Ajax - an offer he subsequently turned down. Fandi's Muslim faith is central to his life. He avoids scandals, does not smoke or drink, and has been described as humble, filial, and compassionate. In this extended edition of Weekend One on One, he talks to SBS's Christopher Tan

item.title: Republican Albanese meets the King, as Opposition questions taxpayer bill for UK trip
item.description: Sussan Ley has struck out at Anthony Albanese attending a UK Labour Party conference, saying he isn't in the UK as ALP leader. The prime minister said he has important ministerial meetings at the conference, and he's also met with the UK Opposition leader.

item.title: INTERVIEW: 'We are family, we should work together': Palau President's challenge to Australia
item.description: Palau, an independent island nation in the western Pacific Ocean, consists of more than 300 islands in Micronesia. It's a popular destination for divers and ecotourists and visitors are required to take the "Palau Pledge" to protect its ecosystems. But Palau is already facing the immediate reality of climate change, with rising sea levels, coral bleaching, extreme weather events, and biodiversity loss. Surangel Whipps Junior, the President of Palau, has spoken at the United Nations General Assembly in New York, and wants to see the COP31 global climate conference held in the Pacific region rather than in Turkiye, because this is where climate change is already having devastating impacts. He's been talking to SBS Senior International Correspondent Ben Lewis, and told him that Palau and Australia are family - and the two countries need to work together.

item.title: MSF suspends Gaza City health activities as Hamas denies reports of an in-principle truce
item.description: Hamas has contradicted a prominent Israeli newspaper's report that it had agreed in principle to a truce deal proposed by the US president.

item.title: The effects of Tonga's massive volcanic explosion linger, three years on
item.description: It's been more than three and a half years since one of the most powerful volcanic eruptions in recent history left devastation in Tonga. An Australian-led scientific team has been studying the area surrounding the underwater volcano, in collaboration with researchers from across the world, looking for signs of life. The eruption changed the shape of the sea floor and devastated the underwater environment but early signs of life are beginning to emerge.

item.title: Russia says West will 'very much regret' any aggressive action inside its airspace
item.description: The Russian foreign minister also said that only the "politically blind" would expect Ukraine to return to pre-2022 borders, an indirect response to a recent assertion made by the US president.

item.title: Donald Trump deploys troops into another US city, authorising use of 'full force, if necessary'
item.description: The Portland mayor and Oregon governor have both rejected Donald Trump's planned deployment of the US military into the north-western city.

item.title: The hidden form of sexual assault you may not know about
item.description: Stealthing — the removal of a condom during sex without a partner's knowledge or consent — is criminalised in most of Australia. But experts warn many people remain unaware of what it is and the risks it poses.

item.title: The hidden form of sexual assault you may not know about
item.description: Stealthing — the removal of a condom during sex without a partner's knowledge or consent — is criminalised in most of Australia. But experts warn many people remain unaware of what it is and the risks it poses.

item.title: What to know about UN's 'snapback' sanctions on Iran, reimposed after a decade
item.description: The "snapback" process reactivates UN resolutions, but their practical implementation requires UN member states to update their laws to comply.

item.title: Russia's major drone and missile attack on Ukraine kills four in Kyiv
item.description: Russia rained down 643 drones and missiles, including glide bombs, across eastern, central and southern Ukraine, Ukraine's general staff said.

item.title: Breast cancer patients in Australia to save thousands as new drug added to PBS
item.description: Without the subsidy, patients were facing costs of $100,000 for treatment.

item.title: 'Part of my job': Albanese fires back at critics questioning his taxpayer-funded UK itinerary
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese addressed concerns about participating in a party-political event in an interview with SBS News.

item.title: Nuclear bombs on drones: The next arms race that has experts 'very concerned'
item.description: While drones flying over different parts of Europe have raised concerns in many countries, some are worried about a more dystopian future with the technology.

item.title: In America's war on autism, families like Eileen's are on the frontline
item.description: US health secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr has faced widespread criticism over his comments about autism. And in a changing America, community members from all parts of the spectrum are navigating societal and political divisions.

item.title: Anthony Albanese stands by Palestinian statehood recognition | Morning News Bulletin 29 September 2025
item.description: Anthony Albanese reaffirms the federal government's choice to recognise Palestinian statehood; Ukraine's President condemns a deadly 12-hour aerial bombardment targeting Kyiv and other regions; And in AFL, Ally Anderson marks her 100th AFLW game in style.

item.title: Four people dead, several injured after shooting at US Mormon church
item.description: The suspect was shot dead by police after allegedly setting the building on fire.

item.title: Working in a Gaza field hospital: The view from an Australian emergency nurse
item.description: An Australian nurse is among the few international staff still on the ground at a Red Cross field hospital in southern Gaza. He shares the challenges of working in one of the only facilities still fully functioning in the enclave.

item.title: 'In real danger': Hamas says it lost contact with two hostages during Israeli offensive
item.description: Hamas's armed wing said the hostages' lives were under threat and called on Israeli forces to "immediately withdraw".

item.title: Jobs and wages boost budget bottom line ahead of Tuesday's interest rates call
item.description: Strong jobs and wages numbers have more than halved the budget deficit that was projected last financial year.

item.title: Calls mount for independent inquiry into Optus triple-zero failures
item.description: The beleaguered telco revealed it's investigating yet another outage, with customers in NSW cut off from emergency calls over the weekend.

item.title: Communications Minister to meet with Optus bosses | Midday News Bulletin 29 September 2025
item.description: The Communications Minister to meet with Optus bosses, following a succession of triple-zero outages; Australia's budget deficit shrinks to $10 billion; And in rugby, England's women's team celebrate their win over Canada.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 29 September 2025
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners, and people with a disability.

item.title: Trump hints at Middle East peace plan: 'All on board for something special'
item.description: The prospect of a long-awaited Middle East peace initiative has re-emerged, with President Donald Trump signalling that his administration is ready to unveil a comprehensive plan for Gaza. While US and Israeli leaders express cautious optimism, the humanitarian crisis in Gaza continues to worsen, with tens of thousands dead and entire neighbourhoods reduced to rubble.

item.title: 'Weird weather': Why this year's spring and summer just became tricky to predict
item.description: A clash of wind and air currents 30km above Antarctica has suddenly thrown Australia's spring and summer weather forecast into question.

item.title: Police pursuit ends in Bourke Street Mall, multiple arrests in Melbourne CBD
item.description: Four teenagers have been arrested after police saw a vehicle being driven "erratically".

item.title: Moldova's pro-EU party wins surprise majority in election hit by Russian meddling claims
item.description: The small European Union candidate nation has long been divided over whether to move closer with Brussels or maintain Soviet-era relations with Moscow.

item.title: Tony Blair: Ruler of Gaza? Why the former British leader is suddenly in the frame
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has praised former UK prime minister Tony Blair for his "constructive" involvement in the Middle East.

item.title: What happened to an Australian republic? Why Albanese has quashed the idea
item.description: The prime minister isn't willing to risk his renewed political capital by holding another referendum, experts argue.

item.title: Coalition calls for independent inquiry into Triple-zero ecosystem | Evening News Bulletin 29 September 2025
item.description: The Coalition calls for an independent inquiry into Triple-zero ecosystem; High-risk domestic violence offenders could soon be forced to inform police when using dating apps; And in the NRL, The Broncos celebrate booking a spot in the Grand Final.

item.title: Brisbane Broncos light up sharemarket & final budget outcome revealed
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Stephen Smith from Deloitte Access Economics abut what the government's final budget outcome says about the economy; plus Kyle Rodda from Capital.com on the day's sharemarket action.

item.title: 'Significant discrepancies' found in imported melatonin products, medical regulator warns
item.description: Testing of unregulated melatonin revealed one product contained four times its labelled amount, while another did not have any at all.

item.title: Here are the travel destinations Australians are heading to this spring
item.description: Many Australians will be heading out of state or the country this spring but cost is proving to be one of the greatest barriers for making plans.

item.title: First Nations youth train as firefighters to defend Country and Community: 'I want to make a difference'
item.description: A group of young First Nations men and women have blazed their way through a training program for firefighter hopefuls. The initiative is a partnership between TAFE and the New South Wales Fire Service - to help young Indigenous people get into their dream job.

item.title: Natural disasters are growing; could an army of young volunteers help?
item.description: Could a 'Climate Army' of young volunteers bolster Australia's capability to cope with natural disasters? That's the question before a Senate inquiry looking at proposals for a new national scheme.

item.title: Dozens killed as Typhoon Bualoi batters Vietnam and Philippines
item.description: In Vietnam, Bualoi made landfall as a typhoon late on Sunday, generating winds of 130 kmh.

item.title: 'They destroy lives': How property investors lost millions to a failed housing scheme
item.description: A group of Iranians were told that investing in Australian specialist disability accommodation would be as safe as houses. However, those plans never eventuated, and they've collectively lost $1,178,500.

item.title: Spouses for sale: Inside the black market for skilled visa applications
item.description: SBS has uncovered a black market operating on apps targeting members of the Chinese community, selling places for "spouses" in permanent residency skilled visa applications.

item.title: Australia supports Trump's 20-point Gaza peace plan backed by Israel
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the country "welcomes President Trump's plan to bring peace to Gaza after almost two years of conflict and a devastating loss of civilian life".

item.title: Australia supports Trump's 20-point Gaza peace plan backed by Israel
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the country "welcomes President Trump's plan to bring peace to Gaza after almost two years of conflict and a devastating loss of civilian life".

item.title: Trump, Netanyahu agree on a new plan for Gaza | Morning News Bulletin 30 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, Israel and US agree to a plan for ending the war in Gaza; Pressure mounts on Optus after their latest triple zero bungle; and in tennis, An historic opportunity for Aussie Alex De Minaur at the China Open.

item.title: Vital role of translators celebrated amid AI challenge
item.description: It's been eight years since the United Nations first recognised International Translation Day. The celebration falls on 30 September and recognises the work of language professionals who foster cultural understanding, connection and social cohesion. But some translators and interpreters in Australia believe more needs to be done to protect the workforce and bridge language barriers.

item.title: Albanese invites Arab 'hypermarket' to compete with Coles and Woolworths
item.description: As Australia grapples with a supermarket monopoly, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese hopes the expansion of this Emirati "hypermarket" might bring in some competition.

item.title: JK Rowling lashes out at 'ignorant' Emma Watson over trans rights row
item.description: The author criticised the Harry Potter star, who said in a recent interview that she can still love people with whom she disagrees.

item.title: The country under internet blackout after cables cut over 'vice' and immorality
item.description: The country is experiencing a total connectivity blackout, according to Netblocks, the internet watchdog.

item.title: Hamas reviewing Gaza peace plan | Midday News Bulletin 30 September 2025
item.description: Hamas now reviewing a Gaza peace plan; The Communications Minister meeting with Optus' major shareholder after two devastating triple zero outages; And in sport, Mitch Brown unhappy over a Mad Monday post he says is homophobic.

item.title: 'Hearts are aching': Family of missing preschooler release statement as search continues
item.description: Four-year-old Gus disappeared from his family's remote South Australia property on Saturday afternoon.

item.title: Police to consider findings after woman awarded 93k over 'humiliating' strip search
item.description: NSW Police did not have reasonable grounds to search the reveller at the 2018 Splendour in the Grass event, the NSW Supreme Court has found.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 30 September 2025
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Not the outcome Australians wanted, Chalmers says, as Reserve Bank holds cash rate
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia board was widely tipped to hold the cash rate after inflation data showed successive rises.

item.title: 'Disappointing': Critics say Riyadh Comedy Festival has an unfunny human rights problem
item.description: Comedy heavyweights including Dave Chappelle, Jimmy Carr and Louis CK are on the bill of the Riyadh Comedy Festival.

item.title: Middle East peace talks: US, Israel propose plan as Hamas weighs response
item.description: Israel and the United States have agreed to a plan for ending the war in Gaza. But both US President Donald Trump and Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu have indicated if Hamas rejects the plan, the militant group will face the consequences. Hamas says it is reviewing the proposals.

item.title: New guidelines developed for helping people with dementia
item.description: A framework has been developed to track and improve the treatment options for dementia patients in aged care. The proposal come after the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare named dementia as the leading cause of death in Australia.

item.title: Key questions around the 'tone deaf, very tricky' Trump-Netanyahu Gaza peace plan
item.description: A United States proposal for peace in Gaza has received endorsement from Israel and the Palestinian Authority, but its long-term success is on a knife-edge.

item.title: The Reserve Bank keeps interest rates on hold | Evening News Bulletin 30 September 2025
item.description: The Prime Minister welcomes a US-Israeli plan for peace in Gaza; The Reserve Bank keeps interest rates on hold; And in sport, Australia records its first gold medal at the World Para Athletics Championships.

item.title: The PM's new supermarket proposal might cut your bills, but it's 'no silver bullet'
item.description: The prime minister needs to consider preconditions, such as space and a break-up of Coles and Woolworths, if he wants a competing supermarket to thrive and bring down prices.

item.title: Optus faces backlash over triple-zero failures, with calls for consequences
item.description: A meeting between Communications Minister Anika Wells and leaders from Optus and its parent company, Singtel, has yielded little new information or action. It comes as calls for stronger consequences grow in the wake of multiple triple-zero failures that have been linked to deaths. Critics say there's more the minister could be doing right now to restore public trust.

item.title: 'The pinnacle': One of Australia's most dominant teams aims at 40-year record
item.description: Australia's women's cricket side take on New Zealand in their first World Cup match.

item.title: RBA holds fire; energy stock sell-off
item.description: Despite solid gains by the gold miners, a sell-off in energy stocks – fuelled by a continued decline in oil prices – has dragged the Australian sharemarket. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Jonathan Shead, Head of Investment at State Street Investment Management. Plus, the Reserve Bank left interest rates unchanged at 3.6 percent, as expected, at its September board meeting. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Pradeep Philip from Deloitte Access Economics.

item.title: Decision to allow registered nurses to prescribe medicines solves many health service problems
item.description: Tens of thousands of registered nurses across the country will be able to up-skill to prescribe medications usually authorised by a doctor. It's a reform that could change the medical landscape in Australia... and the lives of many patients.

item.title: 'Very sad end': Hamas under pressure as Trump issues deadline on Gaza peace plan
item.description: Mediators from Qatar and Egypt shared the document with Hamas, which was not involved in negotiations in the lead-up to the 20-point plan.

item.title: Pizza, porn, and getting high: Inside the grip of a severe tech addiction
item.description: Technology seems a non-negotiable part of everyday life. For Quentin, it became an addiction. After years of trying different ways to break free, it was a 12-step program that helped her into recovery.

item.title: Fast entry or backwards step? What Labor's new housing scheme means for you
item.description: Analysis shows the government's new First Home Guarantee scheme could slash years off savings times — but experts warn it could come at a cost.

item.title: The US is “under invasion from within”: Trump’s plan for the military | Morning News Bulletin 1 October 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, Donald Trump says US cities could be 'training grounds' for the military; The US-led plan for ending the war in Gaza continues to provoke strong reactions; and in tennis, Alex De Minaur goes down to Jannik Sinner again at the China Open.

item.title: 'Invasion from within': Trump says US cities should be used as military training grounds
item.description: Donald Trump said that under his administration, the US military was now "reawakening the warrior spirit".

item.title: Nicole Kidman files for divorce from Keith Urban, citing 'irreconcilable differences'
item.description: Oscar-winning star Nicole Kidman and Grammy-winning country musician Keith Urban had been living apart for some time, according to US media reports.

item.title: SPF slip-ups: More sunscreens withdrawn as TGA finds claims don't stack up
item.description: The Therapeutic Goods Administration has announced 21 more sunscreen products, all linked to the same base formulation, are under review after failing to provide the SPF protection they advertise.

item.title: A new push for peace: What part did Australia play in the 20-point plan for Gaza?
item.description: Anthony Albanese's stopover in the Middle East came after more lengthy engagements in the US — for the leaders' week at the United Nations — and the UK.

item.title: A new push for peace: What part did Australia play in the 20-point plan for Gaza?
item.description: Anthony Albanese's stopover in the Middle East came after more lengthy engagements in the US — for the leaders' week at the United Nations — and the UK.

item.title: New move in latest Optus triple-zero failure, as Albanese says it 'failed customers'
item.description: Anthony Albanese says Optus has "failed" its customers and has called for the company to "be transparent".

item.title: The US government has shut down. What happens now?
item.description: The US government has entered a shutdown, meaning thousands of federal employees are being placed on leave or asked to work without pay until the government reopens.

item.title: The US government has shut down. What happens now?
item.description: The US government has entered a shutdown, meaning thousands of federal employees are being placed on leave or asked to work without pay until the government reopens.

item.title: Government's first home buyers scheme expanded from today | Midday News Bulletin 1 October 2025
item.description: The federal government's expanded first home buyers scheme open from today; cascading impacts after the Taliban imposes a nationwide internet shutdown; and in cricket, Australia prepares to defend its Women's Cricket World Cup trophy, as the team goes up against New Zealand.

item.title: Albanese 'concerned' over China's reported BHP iron ore ban
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese hopes a pricing dispute between China and the Australian mining giant will be resolved "very quickly".

item.title: Hamas, Qatar review peace deal as global reaction remains mixed
item.description: The United Nations has welcomed the US-led peace plan in achieving a ceasefire to end a nearly two-year war for Gaza and the region. But internationally, the plan continues to receive mixed reactions, as Hamas and Qatar mediators review the deal.

item.title: Helpful or spying? Do we really need to track where our loved ones are?
item.description: Psychologists warn that the use of tracking apps like Life360 and FindMyPhone can normalise constant monitoring, which may start in families but spill into intimate partner relationships, potentially leading to controlling and coercive behaviours. But how do we know if tracking those we love is beneficial or problematic? And if it's the latter, how do we address it?

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 1 October 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Immigrants, "wokeness" and obesity: Trump, Hegseth say the US military has challenges
item.description: When hundreds of military commanders were ordered to attend a last-minute meeting in Virginia in the United States, there was speculation of a major announcement. What greeted them was US President Donald Trump and defence secretary Pete Hegseth delivering an impassioned speech on "wokeness", obesity and using US cities as military training grounds.

item.title: Democrats take aim at 'erratic and unhinged' Trump as US government shuts down
item.description: The White House, meanwhile, has blamed the Democrats for the shutdown, which has healthcare as a key sticking point.

item.title: Albanese government urged to cut military ties with Israel | Evening News Bulletin 1 October 2025
item.description: US federal employees stop work as the government goes into shutdown; the Albanese government urged to cut military ties with Israel; and AFL star Buddy Franklin prepares to represent First Nations people at the New York City Marathon.

item.title: Magnitude-6.9 earthquake kills more than 70 people in the Philippines
item.description: The quake, which struck off the central island of Cebu, was the country's deadliest in more than a decade.

item.title: It happened 'by accident', but Mark is helping tackle a $2.7bn Australian problem
item.description: Loneliness among men has been described as a "crisis" in Australia, and its estimated to cost the health system billions each year.

item.title: BHP-China iron ore stand-off; house prices continue to rise
item.description: The Australian sharemarket has fallen flat, as investors react to the US government shutdown and reports of China temporarily banning purchases of BHP’s iron ore. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Niv Dagan from Peak Asset Management. Plus, Australian house prices continue to rise, as the Albanese Government’s Home Guarantee scheme is expanded to all first home buyers. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Tim Lawless, Asia-Pacific research director at Cotality.

item.title: A new First Nations voice to guide Australia's public health sector
item.description: The Public Health Association of Australia has announced they will be establishing an Aboriginal and Torres-Strait Islander voice to help guide their work after a near unanimous vote by their members. Nearly two years after the failed referendum saw a First Nations voice to parliament shot down, NGOs like the PHAA and state governments have chosen to follow the wishes of the majority of Indigenous communities in Australia who voted for this special representation.

item.title: INTERVIEW: What does the US shutdown mean in practice?
item.description: The U.S. federal government has entered a shutdown, a few hours after the U.S. Senate failed to pass a short-term spending bill on Tuesday night US East Coast time. It's the first government shutdown in nearly seven years. The last and also the longest federal government shutdown occurred from late 2018 to early 2019 during President Trump's first term when Democrats opposed funding the U.S.-Mexico border wall. The result was a shutdown lasting over five weeks, during which some 800,000 federal employees were forced to work without pay or take unpaid leave. Hundreds of thousands of federal employees will be forced to take unpaid leave this time too, with some public services potentially suspended or delayed, and the release of economic data possibly impacted as well. Bruce Wolpe is a senior fellow at the University of Sydney's United States Studies Centre and has served on the Democratic staff in the US Congress. He's been speaking to SBS's Virginia Langeberg about the impact of the shutdown.

item.title: Man cleared of involvement after police swoop on property in search for Dezi Freeman
item.description: Police hunting Australia's most wanted fugitive have targeted an area far away from where he was last sighted after he allegedly shot dead two officers.

item.title: Man cleared of involvement after police swoop on property in search for Dezi Freeman
item.description: Police hunting Australia's most wanted fugitive have targeted an area far away from where he was last sighted after he allegedly shot dead two officers.

item.title: Man cleared of involvement after police swoop on property in search for Dezi Freeman
item.description: Police hunting Australia's most wanted fugitive have targeted an area far away from where he was last sighted after he allegedly shot dead two officers.

item.title: 'No more signs of life': Dozens remain missing after Indonesian school collapse
item.description: After days of rescue operations, 59 people were still feared buried under the rubble after at least five people had been confirmed dead.

item.title: Is your sunscreen safe? What to know amid Australia's SPF ratings storm
item.description: Eighteen sunscreens have either been recalled or had their sale paused in Australia. Here's what you need to know as the weather gets warmer.

item.title: In a battle to build, these five charts show Labor's housing headache
item.description: There are doubts major inroads into Australia's housing supply problem can be made in a couple of years and questions over the government's "ambitious" 2029 target. So, what can be done?

item.title: I started feeling sick making lunch — and never could've expected what came next
item.description: Corinne Laurent doesn’t believe she would still be alive if not for her smartwatch.

item.title: Jane Goodall, pioneering scientist and conservationist, dies at 91
item.description: The primatologist drew the public into the wild with her groundbreaking research, later shifting to climate advocacy.

item.title: DFAT ready to assist after six Australians in Gaza flotilla detained
item.description: The Australians were aboard three vessels — Mia Mia, The Spectre, and Wahoo — as part of the Global Sumud Flotilla, which is attempting to break Israel's blockade of Gaza and deliver aid.

item.title: IDF intercepts flotilla | Morning News Bulletin 2 October 2025
item.description: Israel intercepts a flotilla attempting to bring aid to Gaza... a new raid in the hunt for Dezi Freeman... and, in the AFL, Geelong abandons its Mad Monday celebrations

item.title: Wildlife advocate and primate expert Jane Goodall dies at 91
item.description: The renowned conservationist, scientist, and global activist Jane Goodall has died at the age of 91. The Jane Goodall Institute announced the primatologist's death of natural causes on social media.

item.title: See the full list: The biggest Australian companies paying the least tax
item.description: Australia's largest companies paid $95.7 billion in taxes, with those paying zero dropping to an 11-year low.

item.title: Erin Patterson to appeal murder convictions over deadly mushroom lunch, lawyer says
item.description: Patterson's legal team will have 28 days to lodge the relevant paperwork before a court considers whether to approve the appeal.

item.title: Concerns for Australians aboard intercepted flotilla | Midday News Bulletin 2nd October 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, concerns for Australians in Israeli custody after an aid flotilla was intercepted off Gaza, the defence force joins the search for a four-year-old missing from a South Australian sheep property. And in sport, Matildas star Mary Fowler continues her Manchester City career.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 2nd October 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Albanese welcomes PNG's decision to sign landmark defence pact
item.description: The pact will elevate the Pacific partnership, ensuring an attack on one would be a "danger to the peace and security of both countries".

item.title: Albanese welcomes PNG's decision to sign landmark defence pact
item.description: The pact will elevate the Pacific partnership, ensuring an attack on one would be a "danger to the peace and security of both countries".

item.title: Government shutdown begins as division rules Washington
item.description: Washington has ground to a halt thanks to a government shutdown, triggered by Congress being unable to agree on a funding bill. It is the 15th government shutdown since 1981, which will likely slow the release of key reports and lead to the furlough of 750,000 federal workers at a daily cost of $US400 million.

item.title: 'Blood on their hands': Row erupts over Lost Dogs Home's puppy euthanasia decision
item.description: A couple who had fostered the dog, Murphy, had called Victoria's Lost Dogs Home to ask how he was going, only to be told he would be put down.

item.title: Flotilla bound for Gaza despite interception | Evening News Bulletin 2 October 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, multiple boats are still bound for Gaza, despite dozens being intercepted by the Israeli military, Australia signs its defence pact with Papua New Guinea, after weeks of delay. And in sport, Tamika Upton makes history with a second Dally M award.

item.title: Australian men face loneliness crisis: what’s driving it and how to fix it
item.description: Loneliness among men has been described as a "crisis" in Australia, and it appears to be on the rise. This social isolation can not only hurt mens mental health and overall wellbeing, it is also costing the Australian economy billions of dollars. A recent Australian study could hold the answer as to why men appear to be stuggling more with loneliness.

item.title: Gaza peace plan, US shuts down & China combats whingers
item.description: A new 20-point plan for peace in Gaza gains support among the international community. Trump warns the US military of the enemy from within as Hegseth tells Generals to slim down for the war on woke. Plus, Democrats and Republicans point the finger at each other as the US government shuts down. Also, Moscow warns of a new red line in the war in Ukraine. And, China launches a campaign to stamp out online negativity.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Israeli forces take action against flotilla trying to deliver aid
item.description: Israeli military personnel have intercepted an international flotilla trying to deliver medicine and food to Gaza and boarded its boats as it approached the area. The Global Sumud Flotilla consists of more than 40 civilian boats carrying about 500 parliamentarians, lawyers and activists including Swedish climate campaigner Greta Thunberg. The organisers say they are trying to break Israel's blockade of Gaza, despite repeated warnings from Israel to turn back. The United Nations last month ruled that Israel had committed genocide in Gaza, a claim Israel denies. Israel has imposed a naval blockade on Gaza since Hamas took control of the coastal enclave in 2007 and they claim it is a legal part of the action they are taking against Hamas. They've accused the flotilla of having connections to Hamas - which the organisers strongly deny, while other critics accuse them of grandstanding. Judy Patterson's son, Hamish, is the captain of the Wahoo, one of the ships taking part in the action, and she spoke to SBS's Tee Mitchell.

item.title: Nuclear energy sank the Coalition at the election — can it power their comeback?
item.description: The coalition are revamping their proposal for nuclear energy, despite suffering an election loss with this policy. The details are yet to be confirmed, but the Opposition Energy Minister says they will adapt their plan to meet developments in the space.

item.title: NIMBYs, YIMBYs — and BIMBYs: The new group in Australia's housing stoush
item.description: As state governments roll out plans to battle Australia's housing crisis, community groups are mobilising to have a say in how their suburbs are — or are not — changed.

item.title: ASX rallies despite US government shutdown
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Callam Pickering about the latest household spending data and what it means for interest rates, plus Henry Jennings from Marcus Today on the days market action.

item.title: Multiple injured in car and stabbing attack at UK synagogue, suspect shot
item.description: The incident unfolded in the northern UK city of Manchester on Thursday morning local time.
